div.p: Located in Melbourne’s western suburbs the Western
Autistic School serves more than just the needs of its
immediate school and local community.
A registered training organisation, the school provides
state wide and accredited training for teachers working
with children with Asperger’s Syndrome and autism.
Featuring award winning design, the school’s purpose
built campus is a dream come true for students, their
families and teaching staff.
Using more than $2 million in funding under the
Australian Government’s Building the Education
revolution; the Western Autistic School was able to
complete its master plan, providing students, the
school and wider communities with a world class
training and therapy pool.
Officially opening the school’s BER funded facilities,
Prime Minister Gillard reflected on the significant
role they were playing in supporting the school’s
diverse activities.
Now when you invest more than 16 billion dollars in the
schools you make a difference and that’s what we did
through Building the Education Revolution.
We did it at a time when the Australian economy needed
support for jobs because of the global financial crisis.
So when it came to injecting money to support jobs we
decided the best place to put it was into schools.
But with all of that injection of funds and all of the
new school buildings, today is a first for me because
it’s the first time, under Building the Education
Revolution that I have actually had the opportunity to
open a swimming pool.
You have innovated and used that money for a swimming
pool in special circumstances where you deal with
children who wouldn’t have necessarily an inherent
sense of danger and the danger that water can pose to
young people and also a swimming pool which enables
them to have a new outlet for physical and social
activity and for many of the students who come to this
school having that outlet would be a particularly
precious thing.
With an intake of about 80 prep students every year,
the school has grown considerably over the years.
In addition to providing education and school-based
programs, Western Autistic school supports the wider
community across Victoria through a range of outreach,
early intervention and professional development
programs supporting teachers, children diagnosed with
Aspergers and autism and their families.
In her 30 years with the school principal Val Gill has
seen a lot of changes.
The BER funding meant that long planned amenities were
finally able to be completed.
It was a wish list, developed by staff for the
architect, on the best features for a school for
teaching children with autism and the pool was on that
list, but we knew that really it wouldn’t, couldn’t be
funded and would remain a dream.
And then Building Education Revolution and so as a
result of that, and only that, we have a state of the
art teaching pool, and the dream is a reality.
Parents too appreciate the significant role the school
plays in supporting them and their children through
their school years.
For Kim Mace and her son Callem BER funded facilities
have made a huge difference.
The teaching pool is fantastic because my son loves
water and on a sensory level he really gets a lot of
benefit from the swimming and it’s been an issue to try
and get swimming lessons with specialised staff that
know how he works as far as learning and everything so
the teaching pool is going to be just brilliant.
One of the largest school modernisation programs in
decades, the Building the Education Revolution is
supporting children’s learning and growth across a
diverse range of educational settings with positive
benefits expected for many years to come.
